snippet.title: Prince William has 'proper teary moment' during centenary anniversary of Battle of Passchendaele
snippet.content:
Royals attend Passchendaele commemorations 0:38
The Duke of Cambridge has led commemorations for the centenary of the Battle of Passchendaele in Belgium.
July 31st 2017 a day ago /display/newscorpaustralia.com/Web/NewsNetwork/Network News/World/
Prince Charles greets Kate, Duchess of Cambridge, and Prince William. Picture: Darren Staples/Getty Images
Staff writers and agenciesNews Corp Australia Network
Share
PRINCE William has admitted to choking back tears as he paid tribute to the thousands killed at Passchendaele on the 100th anniversary of the famous First World War battle. The British royal told of his emotional reaction to hearing the Last Post at Menin Gate, Ypres, Belgium, with the families of soldiers killed in the bloodbath. He was so moved that he recounted Sunday's service when he met interns who have been showing relatives around cemeteries in Ypres.
Princess Catherine and Prince William lay flowers at the headstones of soldiers who fell in World War One at The Tyne Cot Commonwealth War Graves Cemetery in Zonnebeke, Belgium. Picture: Melanie Wenger/AFPSource:AFP "It was phenomenal - a proper teary moment for me," The Duke of Cambridge said. "At the end it was so amazing. It was very, very moving." On Sunday night, the Duke gave a speech before he and the Duchess of Cambridge heard the Last Post and watched as thousands of poppies cascaded from the ceiling of the gate. Before going to the main ceremony at Tyne Cot on Sunday, he stopped in at another cemetery, Bedford House, to see the graves of five Irish Guardsman killed 100 years ago to the day.
Prince William and UK Prime Minister Theresa May during the ceremony. Picture: Geoff Pugh/Getty ImagesSource:Getty Images The Prince of Wales joined them and joked that he needed his gumboots after going into a still flooded First World War bunker in the town of Zonnebeke, near Ypres. Accompanied by King Philippe and Queen Mathilde of Belgium, he went about nine metres below ground where the air is still fetid and the wooden floorboards are still running with water. There he met the grandson and great-grandson of one of the men who excavated it - Company Sergeant Major Henry Hawtin of 171 Tunnelling Company. He and his team dug it out in 1917 under the ruins of an 11th century church flattened by German artillery.
William and Kate meet an intern for the Commonwealth War Graves Commission. Picture: Andrew Matthews/APSource:AP His grandson, retired RAF Regiment Wing Commander Pete Hawtin, 49, said: "Prince Charles was fascinated to meet relatives of a man who had physically been down there. "He just couldn't believe that men would be that far below ground and how they could survive down there and work." Mr Hawtin, from near Thetford, Norfolk, also pointed to Charles's Gordon Highlanders badge and Welsh Guards insignia. "I am covering all the bases. I am Colonel in Chief of these regiments," the Prince told him. Mr Hawtin's son, Tom, 22, a writer, felt honoured by the interest the prince showed. "It's an incredible honour for Prince Charles to recognise not only my great-grandfather but all the unsung heroes. Tunnelling was a very secret, very dangerous and unseen war," Mr Hawtin said.
